Awkwardly you try to explain your theory to Inspector Littlechild. Ostrog was an insane career criminal who you believe was responsible for the crimes. Littlechild sighs.


"You have been speaking to Macnaghten haven't you?" he asks. "Ostrog is a petty criminal who was in prison for stealing a metal cup at the time of the Ripper killings. In fact he's in prison now for more minor burglaries, he could not be the Ripper."


This has seriously damaged your Reputation.
action_results.action: Mary Pearcey
action_results.result:
Mary Pearcey was probably not Jack the Ripper.


Awkwardly you explain your theory to Inspector Littlechild. Pearcey was an incredibly strong woman who brutally slaughtered a woman and her baby and was living in London at the time of the Ripper murders. Littlechild smiles.


"It's an imaginative theory for sure," he tells you. "But all the witnesses who may have seen the Ripper identified him as a man. Mrs Pearcey's crimes were crimes of passion, why on earth would she cut up prostitutes? We can't ask her now anyway, she was executed thirteen years ago."

 

Your Reputation has been damaged.
action_results.action: Alois Szemeredy
action_results.result:
Alois Szemeredy was possibly Jack the Ripper.


Eagerly you explain your theory to Inspector Littlechild. This slippery and insane Hungarian criminal was responsible for at least one but probably two murders and may well have been in London at the time of the Ripper murders. Inspector Littlechild looks thoughtful.


"It's possible," he agrees reluctantly. "Buy Szemeredy was primarily a burglar and thief rather than a killer. There is nothing to prove he was in London at the time and in fact there's no real evidence against him at all. We'll never know now, he committed suicide years ago."
action_results.action: Francis Tumblety
action_results.result:
Dr Francis Tumblety is Jack the Ripper.


Methodically you explain the solution to Inspector Littlechild.


"This doctor was arrested days after the last Ripper murder and promptly skipped bail and fled to America where he went into hiding," you tell Littlechild. "He hated women but has a fascination with possessing women's organs. He has the charm, intelligence and wealth to trick his victims with valuable gifts and his apearrence generally matches witness descriptions of the Ripper. Finally I can prove he was the Ripper: he wears the three cheap brass rings he stole from Annie Chapman's body at all times."


"You've cracked it," Inspector Littlechild exclaims looking amazed. "Let's arrest Jack the Ripper!"


In the summer of 1903 you cross the Atlantic in an ocean liner accompanied by Inspector Littlechild and three of his detectives but the Ripper will elude you one last time. When you arrive in Rochester, New York, you learn that Tumblety died just two days before, passing away peacefully in his sleep. You go to view the serial killer's body where it lies in the funeral home, Tumblety looks peaceful and seems to wear a faint smile on his face. You remove Annie Chapman's brass rings from his lifeless fingers which he stole from her when he stole her life in that dirty yard all those years ago.


Inspector Littlechild is disappointed and tells you that if Tumblety had lived he surely would have been arrested, convicted and executed. There is no point raising a fuss now. Returning to London you go to Manor Park Gate Cemetery to find Annie Chapman's grave intending to bury her rings with her only to find her grave has already been paved over as workmen build a new street. In death as in life no one cares about London's prostitutes.
action_results.action: George Hutchinson
action_results.result: You go to the Victoria Men’s Working Home on Commercial Road where George Hutchinson was last living but when you are arrive you are in for an unpleasant surprise: Hutchinson has moved out and no one seems to know where he has gone now. No one has heard from him and your efforts to find him are in vain.
action_results.action: James Kelly
action_results.result: Going to the local police station you look over the police files on the hunt for James Kelly. Since his escape from Liverpool five months ago there have been no confirmed sightings of him but unconfirmed rumors indicate he is or is shortly planning to flee to France. Raids on his former home and the homes of his relatives in Liverpool have found no trace of him leaving you at a loss of how to find this clever man.
action_results.action: Alois Szemeredy
action_results.result: Your search for Alois Szemeredy takes you to Budapest where he was last sighted. You are able to trace his medical files which report he has been in and out of lunatic asylums for more than twenty years and police records show he has been arrested repeatedly for theft and attempted murder. His trial for murder in Argentina took six years before ending in unexpectedly in his acquittal, he afterwards returned to Hungary (his birth country) which he left two years ago to parts unknown. Despite all this information you are unable to find no trace of the man himself and return to London.
action_results.action: Dr Francis Tumblety
action_results.result: Learning that Dr Tumblety has indeed fled France back to his native America you book passage on a ship to New York, traveling with an Inspector from Scotland Yard who also wants to interview Tumblety. When you arrive in New York you learn that Tumblety has escaped one step ahead of you, fleeing New York for parts unknown. Despite an extensive search of the city by American lawmen they cannot discover where the elusive Doctor has gone. You do however learn that Tumblety has a criminal record, having been arrested in the past for unlicensed abortions, malpractice and even suspicion of involvement in President Lincoln’s assassination. With no clue of his current whereabouts you have no choice but to return to London.
action_results.action: Tell him Mary Kelly was killed late in the morning by a man she was drinking with
action_results.result:
Inspector Abberline frowns when you tell him about Mrs Maxwell's evidence.


"Yes I spoke to her too, she did sound very sincere didn't she?" he asks. "Personally though I think she has made an honest mistake. She has got Mrs Kelly mixed up with this other woman who she spoke to this morning and thinks they are one and the same. I'm not going to consider this serious evidence and I don't think you should either."


You nod and Abberline smiles, though he still looks a little uncertain by this contradictory evidence.
action_results.action: Tell her you do not think it was Mary Kelly who was killed at all
action_results.result:
Inspector Abberline looks astonished.


"Of all the people I would have thought would have brought into this ridiculous theory you are the last!" he exclaims. "Just because the killer destroyed her face there is no reason to doubt this is Mary Kelly. Joseph Barnett, who has been her boyfriend of the last year and ought to know what she looks like, has identified her. If the dead woman is not Mary Kelly then the real Mary Kelly would have identified herself by now. I don’t think we will make any progress at all if you follow such mad ideas as these."

 

Your Reputation with the police has been damaged.
